<!-- # Geospatial analysis: R for GIS -->

## Introduction

â€¢ Spatial data provide insights

â€¢ *Spread* of a disease, or

â€¢ *Situation* of an outbreak

â€¢ **Where** are the current disease hotspots?

â€¢ How have the hotspots **changed over time**?

â€¢ How is the **access** to health facilities?

![](images/gis_head_image.png)

â€¢ Today, **why to use R** to address these tasks.

## Learning objectives

1.  Define what is a **geospatial analysis**.

2.  Identify the main analytical task that a **GIS software** need to solve.

3.  Identify the **advantages** of R as a GIS software.

## Prerequisites

This lesson requires familiarity with basic R and `{ggplot2}`: if you need to brush up, have a look at our introductory course on R and data visualization.

```{r,eval=TRUE,echo=TRUE,message=FALSE}
if(!require('pacman')) install.packages('pacman')
pacman::p_load_gh("wmgeolab/rgeoboundaries")
pacman::p_load(tidyverse, 
               ggspatial, 
               leaflet, 
               mapview,
               raster,
               spData,
               stars, 
               tmap, 
               here,
               sf)
```

## What is Geospatial analysis?

â€¢ Data with *geographic* locations or coordinates

â€¢ Related to positions on the Earth's surface.

â€¢ Essential to epidemiology.

â€¢ Identify **hot-spots** and potential **high-risk areas** for communicable disease spread;

â€¢ Map of malaria prevalence predictions in The Gambia (Moraga, 2019)

![](images/malaria_gambia_01.png)

â€¢ Let's see how the code looks like!

```{r,message=FALSE,warning=FALSE}
# ðŸ‘‰ first, get packages:

if(!require('pacman')) install.packages('pacman')
pacman::p_load_gh("wmgeolab/rgeoboundaries")
pacman::p_load(tidyverse, ggspatial, leaflet, 
               raster, stars, here)
```

```{r}
# ðŸ‘‰ second, get data:

# country boundaries
gambia_boundaries <- geoboundaries(country = "Gambia", adm_lvl = 1)
# malaria prevalence
gambia_prevalence <- read_rds(here("data", "gambia_prevalence.rds"))
```

```{r}
# ðŸ‘‰ third, plot data:

ggplot() +
  # with a background
  annotation_map_tile(data = gambia_boundaries, zoomin = 0) +
  # plus a prevalence surface
  geom_stars(data = st_as_stars(gambia_prevalence)) +
  # with a color scale
  scale_fill_viridis_c(na.value = "transparent", alpha = 0.75) +
  # and a coordinate system
  coord_sf()
```

â€¢ Here, skills for **geospatial visualization**,

â€¢ To make *accurate*, *elegant* and *informative* maps.

## R as a GIS

â€¢ Geospatial analysis needs a **geographic information system (GIS)**.

â€¢ *Manage*, *analyze*, and *visualize* spatial data.

â€¢ Popular platforms, **ArcGIS** and **QGIS**, are *graphic-user-interface (GUI)*.

â€¢ So **why use R for geospatial work?**

â€¢ Here five of its merits:

### (1/5) Reproducibility:

â€¢ Code is straightforward for anyone to re-run,

â€¢ Easily build on other people's work

â€¢ Facilitates collaboration

â€¢ Paste this code and reproduce in your computer:

```{r,message=FALSE}
# ðŸ‘‰ packages
if(!require('pacman')) install.packages('pacman')
pacman::p_load(sf, ggplot2)

# ðŸ‘‰ data 
nc <- st_read(system.file("shape/nc.shp", package = "sf"),
              quiet = TRUE)
# ðŸ‘‰ plot
ggplot(data = nc) + 
  geom_sf(aes(fill = SID74)) +
  scale_fill_viridis_c()
```

### (2/5)Reporting:

â€¢ `{Rmarkdown}`, `{flexdashboard}` and `{shiny}` to generate reports and *dashboards*.

â€¢ *Interactive* maps with `{leaflet}` instead of `{ggplot2}`:

```{r,message=FALSE}
# ðŸ‘‰ packages
if(!require('pacman')) install.packages('pacman')
pacman::p_load(sf, leaflet)

# ðŸ‘‰ data
nc <- st_read(system.file("shape/nc.shp", package = "sf"),
              quiet = TRUE)

# ðŸ‘‰ plot
pal <- colorNumeric("YlOrRd", domain = nc$SID74)
leaflet(nc) %>%
  addTiles() %>%
  addPolygons(color = "white", fillColor = ~ pal(SID74),
              fillOpacity = 1) %>%
  addLegend(pal = pal, values = ~SID74, opacity = 1)
```

### (3/5) Rich ecosystem:

â€¢ R with rapidly *growing libraries*

â€¢ highly-active open-source community,

â€¢ ready-to-use packages or tutorials.

â€¢ *interactive* map with one line of code!

â€¢ `{mapview}` instead of `{leaflet}`:

```{r,message=FALSE}
# ðŸ‘‰ packages
if(!require('pacman')) install.packages('pacman')
pacman::p_load(sf, mapview)

# ðŸ‘‰ data
nc <- st_read(system.file("shape/nc.shp", package = "sf"),
              quiet = TRUE)

# ðŸ‘‰ plot
mapview(nc, zcol = "SID74")
```

### (4/5) Convenience:

â€¢ You already know R!

â€¢ Explore new pieces of code.

::: rstudio-cloud

As an example, we will use the `{tmap}` package and make minor modifications to it!

First, run this chunk:

```{r,warning=FALSE,message=FALSE}
# ðŸ‘‰ packages
if(!require('pacman')) install.packages('pacman')
pacman::p_load(tmap, spData)

# ðŸ‘‰ data
load(here("data/nz_elev.rda"))

# ðŸ‘‰ plot
tm_shape(nz_elev)  +
  tm_raster(title = "elev", 
            style = "cont",
            palette = "-RdYlGn") +
  tm_shape(nz) +
  tm_borders(col = "red", 
             lwd = 3) +
  tm_scale_bar(breaks = c(0, 100, 200),
               text.size = 1) +
  tm_compass(position = c("LEFT", "center"),
             type = "rose", 
             size = 2) +
  tm_credits(text = "J. Nowosad, 2019") +
  tm_layout(main.title = "My map",
            bg.color = "lightblue",
            inner.margins = c(0, 0, 0, 0))
```

Now, apply any of the following suggestions to get used to how this package works:

1.  Change the **map title** from "My map" to "New Zealand".
2.  Update the **map credits** with your own name and today's date.
3.  Change the **color palette** to "BuGn".
4.  Try **other palettes** from <http://colorbrewer2.org/>
5.  Put the **north arrow** in the top right corner of the map.
6.  Improve the **legend title** by adding the legend units.
7.  Increase the number of breaks in the **scale bar**.
8.  Change the **borders' color** of the New Zealand's regions to black.
9.  Decrease the line width.
10. Change the **background color** to any color of your choice.
:::
